author: /news/author/joel-bagloletipranks-com
title: Amazon (AMZN) Workers Hold Black Friday Strike to Protest Wages and Working Conditions
text:
Amazon [(AMZN)](https://www.tipranks.com/stocks/amzn) workers around the world are staging a strike from Black Friday through Cyber Monday this weekend to protest their wages and working conditions.
Don't Miss our Black Friday Offers:
- Unlock your investing potential with TipRanks Premium -
[Now At 40% OFF!](https://lp.tipranks.com/black-friday-2024-premium2/?coupon=bfcm24p40&sku=3256820&llf=campaign-article-promo&timer=on&custom18=article) - Make smarter investments with
[weekly expert stock picks from the Smart Investor Newsletter](https://lp.tipranks.com/black-friday-2024-smartinvestor/?coupon=bfcm24si40per&sku=3483380&llf=campaign-article-promo&timer=on&custom18=article)
Calling the action “Make Amazon Pay Day,” workers are holding strikes in more than 20 countries, including the U.S., India, and Canada, to protest what they call “exploitation.” The so called “days of resistance” are being organized by several unions, including UNI Global Union and Progressive International.
The strike comes during the start of the busy [year-end holiday shopping season](https://www.tipranks.com/news/thanksgiving-online-sales-surge-4-as-retailers-double-down-on-discounts), when retailers such as Amazon discount items for the Black Friday and Cyber Monday sales events that fall around U.S. Thanksgiving. This is the fifth year in a row that workers at Amazon have staged protests during the holiday weekend.
Business as Usual
In a statement, Amazon accused the organizers of the job action of promoting a “false narrative” about the company and its pay and benefits. It’s not clear exactly how many workers in the U.S. or abroad are taking part in this year’s strike actions.
Amazon has not said if the protests disrupt its operations or not. However, there’s no question that the strikes come at a busy time. Amazon has announced plans to hire 250,000 seasonal workers for the year-end holidays, and the company has said that it expects online holiday shopping to grow 5% from last year and hit a record $240 billion.
Earlier this week, JPMorgan Chase [(JPM)](https://www.tipranks.com/stocks/jpm) named Amazon the [best stock to own](https://www.tipranks.com/news/amazon-amzn-is-the-best-stock-for-the-year-end-holidays-says-jpmorgan-chase) heading into the year-end holidays owing to the robust online shopping expected between now and Christmas.
[Amazon’s stock has risen 35%](https://www.tipranks.com/stocks/amzn) this year.
Is AMZN Stock a Buy?
Amazon stock has a consensus Strong Buy rating among 46 Wall Street analysts. That rating is based on 45 Buy and one Hold recommendations issued in the last three months. There are no Sell ratings on the stock. The [average AMZN price target](https://www.tipranks.com/stocks/amzn/forecast) of $239 implies 16% upside from current levels.

author: Janelle Ash
title: Billy Crystal describes pain of losing home in Palisades Fire at FireAid benefit concert: 'Fell to my knees'
text:
Billy Crystal describes pain of losing home in Palisades Fire at FireAid benefit concert: ‘Fell to my knees’ Janelle Ash Fri, January 31, 2025 at 4:22 AM UTC 4 min read
Billy Crystal describes pain of losing home in Palisades Fire at FireAid benefit concert: ‘Fell to my knees’ Billy Crystal, who lost his home in the Palisades Fire, shared a moving message at the LA FireAid Benefit Concert on Thursday night at the Kia Forum.
Following Green Day's performance, Crystal took the stage to introduce the show, with proceeds going to a non-profit, supporting displaced families, rebuilding of infrastructure as well as advancing fire protection technologies.
"Our goal is simple tonight, to raise more money than the Dodgers spent on free agents," the comedian joked.
Billy Crystal, who lost his home in the Palisades Fire, shared a moving message at the LA FireAid Benefit Concert on Thursday night at the Kia Forum. Crystal explained that Steve Ballmer, the owner of the Los Angeles Clippers and the Intuit Dome, would be matching everyone's donation, $1 for $1, on Thursday night.
Advertisement Advertisement Advertisement California Fires: Essential Phone Numbers For Los Angeles-area Residents And How You Can Help Them
The first donation of the night was from U2 for $1 million, which Ballmer will be matching, Crystal said.
Read On The Fox News App
"You'll be hearing from a number of people who were tragically affected by these fires, and I was one of them. These were the clothes I wore when I fled my house with my wife Janice, like so many of us did, on January 7th. This was all I had. Wore it for a week, plus an N-95 mask."
A view of Billy Crystal's home destroyed in the Palisades Fire.
Crystal lived in his Palisades home for 46 years. "I looked like an evacuee or someone that just robed a 7-11," Crystal joked.
Advertisement Advertisement Advertisement Crystal explained that 23 years ago, he took the stage at Madison Square Garden to hold a benefit following 9/11. He explained that he walked out to a grieving audience, holding up posters with pictures of their loved ones asking if anyone had seen them.
Like What You’re Reading? Click Here For More Entertainment News
"And tonight, here I am, talking to all of you in pain, but now I am also one of the hurting thousands, asking, ‘Have you seen my school? Have you seen my church? Have you seen my house? Have you seen my town? Have you seen the 29 people who lost their lives? Have you seen them?’" Crystal said.
Janice and Billy Crystal evacuated their home on Jan. 7. Advertisement Advertisement Advertisement Crystal explained that following 9/11, he was honoring many first responders and firefighters who lost their lives.
"Tonight, we're here together to thank them and all those who run towards danger while we run to shelter and safety," Crystal said.
Billy Crystal Posts ‘When Harry Met Sally’ Throwback To Celebrate 75Th Birthday
He paused to applaud the first responders, with some attending the benefit concert on Thursday night.
WATCH: Inuit Dome owner details how the FireAid benefit concert came to be
"When we were finally able to get back to our house in the Palisades, which I lived in for 46 years, like thousands of you, our house now looked like this," Crystal said, before a photo of the aftermath of the Palisades Fire appeared on the screen.
Advertisement Advertisement Advertisement "I stepped onto the grounds and fell to my knees and I wailed. I had not cried like that since I was 15 years old, and I was told that my father had just died. I remember looking in the mirror back then with my whole life ahead of me thinking, ‘What’s my life gonna be like without him?'"
Click Here To Sign Up For The Entertainment Newsletter
"And now folks, I'm 76-years-old, without a mirror and a lot less life to ponder thinking, ‘What is my life going to be like without our home?’" Crystal asked.
Crystal explained that while visiting the grounds of what used to be his home for 46 years, his daughters ran over with a rock that had "laughter" engraved on it.
Billy Crystal said "we will laugh again" following the LA Fires. "Even in your worst pain folks, it's okay and it's important to laugh," he said. "When I held that rock in my hands, this was the only thing that was left, I thought it was a message from 15-year-old me, saying ‘It’s gonna be okay and it will be okay.' "
Advertisement Advertisement "With your help around the country and here in the room, we will laugh again. We are going to listen to music again and we will be okay," Crystal said.
Original article source: Billy Crystal describes pain of losing home in Palisades Fire at FireAid benefit concert: ‘Fell to my knees’

author: People
title: Genie Bouchard celebrates holidays with family in Montreal: 'Merry Christmas from the gang'
text:
Yahoo Canada Style Genie Bouchard celebrates holidays with family in Montreal: 'Merry Christmas from the gang' The 29-year-old athlete spent the holidays with her family in her hometown of Montreal. Read full article Ellie Spina · Writer Updated December 28, 2023 at 6:49 p.m. · 2 min read Genie Bouchard is spending the holidays with her family in her hometown. (Photo by Matt McNulty/Getty Images for ITF)
Genie Bouchard is sharing a glimpse of how she spent the holidays with her family .
The Canadian tennis star, 29, took to Instagram on Wednesday with a carousel of "cozy" candid photos celebrating Christmas morning with her loved ones in her hometown of Montreal.
In the snaps , the athlete went makeup-free and wore her hair in a loose ponytail, while she matched her family in blue and green flannel pyjamas paired with white slippers. The four of them posed in front of a festive backdrop, including a Christmas tree, small wreath and fireplace.
Bouchard kept her caption short and sweet, wishing her fans a merry Christmas "from the gang."
View this post on Instagram
A post shared by Genie Bouchard (@geniebouchard)
In the comments, fans wished Bouchard a merry Christmas and praised her "adorable" family photo.
Christie Brinkley , model, actress and mother of Bouchard's boyfriend, Jack Brinkley Cook , commented in both English and French, nodding to Bouchard's French-Canadian roots: "Merry Christmas, beautiful Bouchards! Joyeux Noël!"
"Merry Christmas. Beautiful family," a fan wrote .
"Good genes," someone else quipped .
"Adorable! I love a Canadian family Christmas photo. Classic! Happy holidays to you and yours," commented another.
"Did someone say cozy?!" another added .
Earlier this month, the Montreal-native shared her love for winter fashion with another carousel of photos on Instagram.
View this post on Instagram
A post shared by Genie Bouchard (@geniebouchard)
Posing outdoors in New York City, Bouchard donned a pair of blue ripped jeans, a white knit Aritzia top, a long beige coat from Max Mara and white pointed-toe knee-high Stuart Weitzman boots. Completing her look, the athlete accessorized with a thin black leather belt and a taupe Hermès handbag.
She celebrated the brisk weather in her caption, writing , "I get so excited dressing up for cold weather."
Story continues Fans swooned over Bouchard's look and poked fun at her "Canadianness."
"Canadian girlies know how to dress in cold weather, period," an Instagram user quipped .
"Very pretty, fellow Canadian," someone chimed in .
"Looking very stylish, Genie," penned another.
One fan joked : "Your Canadianness is showing."
Let us know what you think by commenting below and tweeting @ YahooStyleCA ! Follow us on Twitter and Instagram .
